thread.title: Mary mulls massive punt on Red V teen star
thread.title_full: Mary mulls massive punt on Red V teen star

title: Mary mulls massive punt on Red V teen star
text:
NRL 2017: Dragons young gun Jai Field a genuine contender for round one John Dean, FOX SPORTS February 2, 2017 2:29pm 
ST GEORGE Illawarra young gun Jai Field is a genuine contender for the Dragons No. 7 jersey according to coach Paul McGregor. 
The race to partner Gareth Widdop in the halves is well and truly on with four players in the running. 
Field, along with Josh McCrone, Kurt Mann, Shaun Nona have all been put through their paces during pre-season training and will get equal time to impress in the upcoming trials against Wests Tigers and South Sydney. 
And despite Field weighing just 78kg, McGregor will have no hesitation of handing the 19-year-old his NRL debut if his trial form permits. media_camera Jai Field at Dragons training. Picture: Brett Costello 
“He’s a very resilient kid and handles training quite well which is great because it’s his first pre-season,” McGregor said. 
“The last three months he hasn’t missed any contact (training). 
“He’s the fittest and our quickest player and that’s important when a young man is coming through. 
“But he’s untried, so in the trials we’ll really see how he stands up. 
“If he gets through that well, and he performs better than the other players, he’ll get the opportunity.” 
Another young star who has been impressing during the pre-season is Matt Dufty. 
There had been some speculation McGregor was toying with the idea of moving Josh Dugan to the centres to accommodate the 21-year-old at fullback, but the coach dismissed the switch — for now. media_camera St George Illawarra player Matt Dufty. Picture: Gregg Porteous 
“Josh will be fullback at this stage,” McGregor said. 
“’Duff’ will get a really good opportunity through the trials because Josh won’t play in the Tigers trial. 
“If Duff comes up with something special, things can change pretty quickly in rugby league, because Josh can play right centre. 
“We’ve got to remember, it’s his first year out of NYC. 
“The best thing for him at this stage is to keep working hard at training and certainly take that opportunity through the trials and you never know. 
“Again, if he’s good enough, he’ll be getting an opportunity in first grade.” 
McGregor said he wouldn’t consider transitioning Dufty into first grade via the wing like some players have done in the past. 
“I don’t believe in age or size, I believe in talent,” he said. 
“He’s a very talent footballer. This is his second pre-season so he’s in much better shape this year than he was last year. 
“He’s a fullback because he’s a very good ballplayer. He’d be wasted on the wing and you probably need more size in bringing the ball back on the wings. 
“His talent lies in his ball playing ability and his speed.”
